metadata.title: Convert Radians to Arcseconds - Angle Converter
metadata.description: Instantly convert an angle value from radians to arcseconds using the SI-consistent relationship. Includes precise formula, worked examples, and practical notes for instrumentation and reporting.

introduction: This converter transforms an angle measured in radians into arcseconds, a common unit in astronomy, surveying, optics, and high-precision engineering. The conversion follows the SI-derived relationship between radians and degrees, and the definition of an arcsecond as 1/3600 of a degree.

Use this tool for quick lookups, verification of calculation pipelines, or preparing values for instrumentation (telescopes, theodolites, interferometers) where angular resolution is expressed in arcseconds. For traceable unit definitions and recommended notation see international standards and national metrology guidance.
methodology: A radian is defined as the ratio of arc length to radius; it is the SI coherent unit for plane angle and is dimensionless. A full circle equals 2π radians.

An arcsecond is a subdivision of the degree: 1 degree = 60 minutes = 3600 arcseconds. Conversion uses the exact mathematical relationships between radians and degrees, and between degrees and arcseconds.

This converter applies the exact formula arcseconds = radians × (180 / π) × 3600. For convenience a high-precision constant (≈ 206264.80624709636 arcsec per radian) is used when displaying numeric outputs.
how_is_calculated: Step 1: Convert radians to degrees using degrees = radians × (180 / π).
Step 2: Convert degrees to arcseconds using arcseconds = degrees × 3600.
Compact formula: arcseconds = radians × (180 / π) × 3600 ≈ radians × 206264.80624709636.
examples: Example 3 — Convert a small angle commonly used in astrometry: 4.84813681109536e-6 rad ≈ 1 arcsecond (since 1 arcsecond = π / 648000 radians).

faqs.question: What is the exact mathematical relationship between radians and arcseconds?
faqs.answer: arcseconds = radians × (180 / π) × 3600. Equivalently, 1 radian ≈ 206264.80624709636 arcseconds.

faqs.question: How many significant figures should I keep for instrument work?
faqs.answer: Keep precision consistent with your instrument's resolution and uncertainty budget. For human-eye or handheld surveying, 1–2 significant figures in arcseconds is sufficient; for telescopes or interferometers, report to the resolution limit (sub-arcsecond) and include measurement uncertainty per ISO/IEC and NIST guidance.

faqs.question: How do I convert back from arcseconds to radians?
faqs.answer: Use radians = arcseconds × (π / 180) / 3600, or radians = arcseconds × (π / 648000).

faqs.question: Why use radians instead of degrees when calculating?
faqs.answer: Radians are the SI-coherent unit for angle and simplify many mathematical expressions (calculus, small-angle approximations). Convert to arcseconds only for reporting or comparing with instrumentation specifications.

faqs.question: Are there standard references for these unit definitions?
faqs.answer: Yes. The SI brochure and national metrology institutes document unit definitions and recommended practices. Use those references for traceability and when preparing calibration or uncertainty statements.

faqs.question: What rounding or formatting is appropriate for automated pipelines?
faqs.answer: Round results to a number of decimal places that preserves the meaningful digits given upstream uncertainty. For automated pipelines, preserve full double precision internally and round only at the final presentation layer; log conversion formulas and constants for reproducibility.
